When they finally fixed those issues but online play was still nearly impossible to enjoy, I believed we'd get improved netcode at some point.  When they accidentally wiped 100% of my save data and unlockables, and offered 'Everything in the Krypt!' (of which I'd already unlocked 80%) as compensation, I was definitely upset. Of the series, I've only played Mortal Kombat 9 prior to this, on the PC. I loved it. The story, the feel of the combat, Johnny Cage. So I was pretty pumped to hear that MKX was on its way.   At release and for the next year and a half, there were issues with netcode and performance on middle of the range computers. There was a recent patch that really fixed a lot of the performance drops I was noticing. I am running what would now be classed as a low end machine, and it can still run the game at 1920x1080 on low with some spikes here and there, where as before I had to lower the resolution significantly. Apparently the netcode is much better, but I'm in Australia, so no amount of software wizardry will help our small population and crap internet.  As for the combat, it is so damn smooth. I loved 9 because I thought it felt great, but now that feels slow and clunky. Everything just flows. You will need to play to understand what I mean, as I won't be able to get it across in words. The characters are quite varied, allowing for all manner of play styles. Each character has 3 variations (and one has an extra secret one you can go and hunt down if you are interested), which really allows you to tailor a character to your needs. The DLC characters are quite expensive, but they are good fun. Kombat Pack 2 is especially good. Try to nab them on special, but really they are not crucial; the game will still be very satisfying without them, and you won't feel underpowered against people using them.  The story is good, but didn't feel as good as 9 for some reason. The cut scenes were done really well, and bridged into combat nicely. The living towers are a good addition, but it is a bit of a shame that the Challenge Tower has been removed. Another feature I miss is having tag teams so that you could coop. Otherwise everything else in this game has just been made bigger and better.  Graphically, the game is incredible. Even on low settings it looks really good. The environments are really detailed, and the particle effects have some really nice qualities to them, such as their patterns, lighting, etc. The Fatalities and the X-Ray moves are all pretty full on, and the Brutalities are nice to have back. The animations during combat are really smooth as well, a lot of time was clearly put in to making them feel good.  Overall, for fighting fans, definitely grab the game, especially now that it has been fixed up. If you are interested in getting into fighting games, this is a good place to start I think, as it can be a bit more forgiving on combos than other fighters. If you aren't interested in fighters, don't get this game, it will offer nothing you want.  You have no idea how much I wanted to substitute all words beginning with C with K....

I waited until they fixed this before buying it when it was on sale.  So I've played this for 8 hours, yeah not that impressive but it doesn't take me long to be interested in something. I must say it's a damn good addition to the franchise!  First off, I'm going to start by saying that I've been playing Mortal Kombat since it's early days on the Super Nintendo and Genesis. Those games never failed to keep me interested, I found them more interesting than the homework I was supposed to be doing, lol. Anyways, onto my review.  What really drew me into this game was the ability to play it locally on PC with my wife and MKX's sheer crazy brutality the installment has (not speaking of the special move) The overall presentation is nice and it feels great. Yes, it is a bit slower than any previous games but it's a good slow. Granted I do prefer the faster combat of the previous game but the fighting in this game actually works to a degree, it actually feels strong and impactful.  Visually, the game is pretty compelling if you have the machine for it (and thank goodness I do!) I mean it's detailed enough to where you actually see beads of sweat on the characters, all the way down to the smaller details in the clothing. Still on visuals, there are times where there's a framerate drop while you're in the middle of fight and it could mean life or death for your character.  As far as sound goes...hmm, well there were times where I had to restart the game to fix some crackling and lipsync to sound mismatching in story mode but if you can hear through all of that, good on you.  The storyline is damn fun for sure, it's like you're immersed into a interactive movie to a large degree. I won't spoil anything for you but it was a good storyline. It takes the events of '98's MK4 on the PC, N64, and PS1 and sugar coats it with some twists and turns but the story is still the same at it's core.  I really wish I could say more but if you're looking for a game to play at parties, a fan of the originals, the need to beat stuff up after a long day at work, gore, and the pleasent sound of bones breaking this game will quench that thirst for sure.  Pros: - Great Graphics, feels real, and looks amazing. - Gameplay is slow, but it delivers a more impactful feel as opposed to previous installments. - Love the amount of characters to choose from. - The Storyline is probably the best one I've seen ever in this franchise.  Cons: - Frequent framerate problems. - Sounds are very crackly at times as well as lipsync mismatches (specifically in Story Mode) - Questionable business practices.  All in all I think it's a fine addition save for the few problems I've mentioned above.  8.5/10

Verdict (tl;dr): 9/10 The game is awesome. In fact, I think it might just be the best fighting game I have ever played. Not 10 out of 10, because it has some things missing. Do not let the low user review rating decieve you: most of the negative reviews don't review the game, but only its launch.  Gameplay and combat: Gameplay is the most important aspect of a fighting game. And in this field Mortal Kombat X truly shines. The movesets are interesting and fluid, and the fights have a really nice pace. The combat mechanisms are a little bit more complex than in MK9, which in my opinion is a good thing, but then again, kombos are pretty easy to learn, so something for everyone here. As a downside some of the moves allow some very cheesy tactics, but this is common in fighting games in general.  All the characters have three different stances from which you pick one before the fight. The stances change some special moves and the way the character is played. Its impact differs from character to character.  Story: No spoilers here, but the story is good for a fighting game. It's not a novel by G.R.R. Martin, but it kept me interested. I was actually surprised how well some of the characters were written.  Roster: The roster is missing out some characters I would have loved to play (for example Baraka), but it's not a huge issue. The game and story has to move forward, right? All in all the roster is full of interesting characters, and some of the new ones really shine.  Performance: Some people have had big performance issues, but I for one get a solid 60fps and everything has been smooth on high settings after I updated to amd's newest beta CCC (Rig: i5 3570k, HD7950 3gb, 8gb ram). There should be more options, for example more AA options. Now there's only FXAA which some people find bad.  Multiplayer: Sometimes it takes a long, long time to find a ranked match online, which sucks. Other than that the online matches have been good. Local multiplayer feels very limited. Tag teams are missing. I would also want to be able to form a local multiplayer team and fight online against other teams. But no.

I think I've played just about every fighter made and I'm going to say this is likely my favorite 2D fighter of all time. It does reward aggression, but it is by no means a shallow game getting by on flash and gore. It balances fun and depth with great success, and it does it looking better than anything I think has ever been done (with Injustice coming up right behind it.)  There were a lot of past MK entries where the characters started to blur together, but this one does a wonderful job of making all of the characters feel unique, and the variations mean that almost any character you want to use has a chance to fit the way you play AND be competitive with high tier characters. For everyone else, if the game goes on sale then it's still a really good buy for someone that isn't looking for online play and doesn't care if they are playing with the latest balancing. I bought and downloaded this game at launch. Even though I have a rig that is more powerful than the recommended specs for this game, the Game still intermittently slows down at times, and then runs normally. Figuring it was rig, I reconfigured the video options, adjusted them down somewhat, but the intermittent slow downs continued. I read online that this slow down issue was due to the way the game launched, downloading patch after patch while simultaneously allowing you to play it. As of this writing, the game doesn't slow down as much, but still lags at times. Note: I have been playing in Single Player and Fection modes so far. I have yet to even touch the online Multiplayer modes.   The features in this MK game are enough for me to recommend this game, despite the glitches experienced at Launch - but with a caveat that you buy the game at a sale price from Steam or another site (and then activate on Steam like I did). The game itself is truly fantastic, with 8 new characters, 16 returning characters, all characters getting 3 distinct fighting styles, Tons of unlockables, and (if you hate unlockables) you have the option to just buy all the unlockable content as DLC. The Kombat Pack is overpriced for only 4 characters, but you can find this at other sites on sale as well, which makes it more worth it, value-wise. It's too bad you have to buy Goro - which was a blatant moneygrab, as his content is visible ingame, but locked behind a pay wall.   The graphics are fantastic, the character design is equally fantastic, as well as the bakground arenas. The Krypt mode, where you roam an area and break tombstones to find unlockables, is an excellent minigame. The Socially networked practice 'King of the Hill' mode is a very fun way to learn the game, and the practice modes are all there from previous MK games. The Story Mode is great, but its attempts to give you an emotional story, with characters who care about each other, is a STARK contrast from MK's gameplay, which allows you to have these characters disembowel each other in gory, gory, GORY fashion. This makes the story mode and the rest of the game feel like disconnected Alternate Universes. Otherwise, the Story mode is a cinematic tour de force, with uneven voice acting, but awesome action sequences.  Get this Game, but get it on sale unless you are ok with paying $129.00 for all the content.

Ok, so if anyone is really mad at WB for abandoning this game I can't blame them. It's a pretty rotten thing to do.  However...  I bought this game after the drop of support had already been announced, so I knew what I was getting into on that front. And once I got past that, I've been more than amazed by the game. I've been an MK fan since I was a teenager playing the original arcade cabinets, and this is easily up there with MK2 and MK9 as the best games in the franchise. Graphics and sound are excellent, the level of detail is ridiculous (just watch some of the stories play out in the backgrounds and you'll see what I mean), and the combat system is easy to pick up yet deep. It's a rare fighting game that both amateurs and hardcore players can excel at, and I much prefer the a la carte combat system in this game to one where I have to push eight buttons in a row or nothing happens.  Also - the living towers in this are genius. Just genius. Sometimes, if I have a few minutes but not enough to play a ton, I'll log on and see what the hourly tower is, play it, then go about my day.  I've logged almost 20 hours and I've only finished half the story and played with half the characters (only a few with all three forms). I've only truly mastered Kitana, and there are even a bunch of her moves/kombos that I haven't fully explored yet. I'm so excited to keep trying new things, and it's going to take me a long, wonderful time to get to it all. The amount of content is staggering.  So bottom line - if the abandonware issue is a deal-breaker, the don't get it and I won't blame you. But if you can live with it, this is truly one of the best fighting games I've played in forever, and it is worthy of the MK name.

Mortal Kombat X is a fighting game that I recommend everyone who enjoys fighting games to try out. If you are a longtime MK fan, then owning the game is a must. I had read review after review about MKX. I was on the fence about whether I should buy it or not. The complaints about lack of PC support and the lack of additional DLC were at the top of my mind. However, my strong appeal for the MK universe won out and I decided to purchase it. I purchased it for full price too, and several of the DLC that looked good to me. I was not disappointed at all.   The gameplay is fairly fast and brutal. If you make just a couple of mistakes, you do not survive the match. The combos are well done, with enough flow to keep the game moving, but not so much that they take up the entire focus of the game. Say, like in KIller Instinct. Great game, completely unrelated to this review, except that in KI, long strung out combos are the focus of the gameplay. In MKX, combos add to what you can do to the opponent, not your only method for winning.   You are free to experiment and implement your own combos with a mix of basic, half combos and special moves. The controls are well done and respond when you press them in the order you tell them to. I did not notice any lag or having to input my combos over and over again to get them to work.  Each character has a different feel and then within that, each character has 3 variations to choose from. Some variations work better for other people. Character choice feels like it is more of a matter of personal preference than anyone being too powerful. A couple of minor exceptions being Jason Vorhees and the Predator, two optional DLC characters. They feel a little over powered for my tastes, but they are still fun to play every now and then.  Graphics of course, are excellent. My only problem with anything graphical or gameplay wise is that my laptop must be plugged in to not have any slowdown. Killer Instinct is the same way, so I believe that my graphics card doesn't run at maximum settings until it is plugged in.  The pricing of the DLC is something that I'm not overly fond of. However, as I enjoy the game, I am more than happy to support the developers for their work and purchase any DLC that I find that adds to my game. The game was a full and complete game when I bought it. The roster was solid, in my opinion. I had no issues with it. When I found out that I could buy a few more characters to add to my game, I was more than happy to shell out a few more dollars to add them. I view the DlC as more like an expansion to the game. Not necessary, required or needed, but definitely appreciated and it adds to the game's lifespan.  Okay, I'll admit that I do not play online, so I cannot rate that aspect of the game. I found out a few years ago that I play like a mix between the CPU being put on hard/medium. I play decent, but am not great. Some players I found that I could crush beneath the weight of my boot. Others I wondered how what they were doing was even possible. I felt like they could read my mind. Throw me when I go to block, hit me high or low, opposite of what I was doing, and juggling me like a professional circus act. So, I don't feel the need to play complete strangers. The local multiplayer, though, is great. Grab an in-law or friend and sit down and beat the other person senseless. Maybe even perform a fatality just to rub it in that you won. So if you have anyone that you can play locally, this game is a great way to pass some time.  For being a fighting game, there seems to be a lot of content with it. The Faction Wars, which I haven't dealt with much yet, so I cannot say how much I like or dislike them. The krypt for unlocking in game costumes, fatalitiies and so on. The traditional arcade style tower mode to find out a specific characters ending that has no bearing on the actual story, but still fun. Living towers that change over time and have different tasks to complete and ways to fight. It all just adds to the game, making a standard 2D fighter a lot more interesting. The story mode is fun, fairly short unfortunately, but continues straight on from MK9. I actually like their reworked stories and how it is progressing. Bringing in children of longtime characters was interesting, but it worked well for me.   Overall, my experience with MKX has been a solid positive experience. The rosters are well rounded, gameplay is clean and tight, graphics are excellent. Fatalities just add to the fun as does local coop. Fans of fighting games should definitely pick this title up.

So far MKX has been a blast...in single player mode. The game runs for me at 60fps almost flawlessly, except for the cutscenes/fatalities and whatnot (which run at 30), but I can live with that. It also looks great and plays smoothly.  What I cannot live with, in the online play.  Both Ranked and unranked matchmaking only work about 10% of the time, and even then it's with constant re-queueing. Rather strange, since I would have thought ranked 1 vs. 1 would be the games most popular online mode. Apparently there's just nobody out there I can be matched with?  I had much more success fighting opponents by joining one of the 'Rooms', this system seems to work much better. You can challenge people within the room, or accept challenges from other people. However, this is also where the real issues begin.  Right from the second I get to the character selection screen upon accepting a challenge, there's a considerably noticable amount of input-lag. So much so that every 5 seconds or so, it won't actually register my button press to scroll across to the next character. In games this is just down-right unplayable. For a game that relies on a trigger finger to block incoming combo's, and then counter within the thin time-frame the game allows, this is just game breaking.  Before you say it, it's not my connection. I'm on a 50mb down and 25mb up wired connection. Even the game displays the maximum amount of 'green bars' for me. However, latency for all opponents (at least with-in one of the games 'Rooms') is always stuck loading, and never actually visible. Perhaps this is lag compensation, I thought, but I couldn't help feeling that all my opponents were having absolutely no problem pulling off intricate combos and blocking all my attacks. I felt like this was only on my end. I've also read plenty of reviews that state that the Online mode is the best yet, and the netcode is far improved over MK 9. So obviously, just isn't effecting everyone.  From there on it gets worse. Huge lags during character selection screens, fatalities, brutalities, you name it. Occasionally my gpu will stop responding altogether, causing a CTD. I'm using the latest driver recently released for GTA V, and everything else works flawlessly with it.  Netherrealm really need to get their ♥♥♥♥ together and fix this. I might try rolling back drivers, but in all honestly I don't see why I should, since everything else on my system is working fine. I'm also skeptical that it would do anything, since the single player modes work great without any input lag or slowdown whatsoever.  I wouldn't recommend picking this up just yet, unless you're only interested in the single player mode. For me Online is where the fun and longevitiy of this game lies, and right now, it's about as fun as being on the receiving end of most of the games fatalities.

This is my second-favorite fighting game of all time, behind Soul Calibur II.  The visuals look great, the combat feels fluid, and the character designs (especially those of the women) are much better than MK9. The new characters are largely a good addition, although the military kids feel a bit bland at times. Like MK9, MKX has a great story mode (especially for a fighter) that lets you play as and get familiar with the new characters. While it's a bit short compared MK9, I still love to see story modes in my fighting games.  This edition of MK has seen a greatly improved version of the Krypt, which plays like a small spinoff of games like Legend of Grimrock. It contains a decent amount of collectables, although I'd like to see more 'making-of' clips along with funny unlockables like the classic 'Cooking With Scorpion.' Mortal Kombat also features more online-integrated features this time around, like the Faction War system and Living Towers. Sadly, the Faction War system has very little depth and ends up just being a method of unlocking more player card items. The Living Towers, however, offer reasons to boot up the game each week and see something new. There are premium weekly towers like those for certain characters or holidays, along with towers which refresh daily and hourly. This helps keep the game more fresh, although MKX is missing a large challenge tower like MK9 had.  While many people have had seemingly endless issues with the PC port, I've been largely unaffected. The launch itself was terrible due to the streaming download feature, but it ran decently well for me. Over the past couple months, the game has had several patches which have brought the quality of the port much closer to that of the console versions. I get a consistent 60 FPS while in combat, which is a great improvement from the regular slowdowns I had right after launch.  I don't really play the game online much, but that has been a major issue I've heard. Apparently fight connection could have been greatly improved, and now there are very few PC players left from the bad launch. It appears that another company has begun patching the game instead of High Voltage Studios, so hopefully the quality of the port only goes up from here. Unfortunately, many of the patches the consoles receive don't seem to come to the PC until the major DLC character releases, so balancing and bonus costumes have been delayed consistently.  Overall, I really enjoy the game. It looks great, plays well, and has good depth with the variation system. While certainly not perfect, I'd definitely recommend this game to lovers of Mortal Kombat or the fighting genre itself.

EDIT: Changed review to 'negative', seeing as Netherealm Studios and Warner Bros. have announced no plans to support this game any further despite being out for less than a year. DO NOT purchase this game, it is no longer being supported.  Mortal Kombat X is the 10th installment in the legendary fighting-game franchise, Mortal Kombat. Coming after Mortal Kombat 9, which undoubtedly delivers one of the best fighting-game experiences of all time, my expectations were pretty high. I was not disappointed; they've done it again! Mortal Kombat X is basically a reconfiguration of the traditional Mortal Kombat formula with a large host of tweaks and configurations. Firstly, the story mode; clocking in at about 6 hours, the campaign is significantly shorter than the previous game, and the character variety throughout is fairly limited. Most of the story mode focuses on the dull, new special forces characters as opposed to some of the more interesting characters. By far, the most interesting segments of the game have you fighting the civil war in Outworld as awesome characters such as Kotal Kahn and D'vorah. Unfortunately, the campaign is quite short and doesn't get as entertaining or substantial as the excellent story mode in MK9. With that said though, there are a lot of great moments and it was a great way to get familiar with many of the characters (many of Takeda's and Kung Jin's moments are pretty fantastic). Speaking of characters, this game includes 25 fighters (I think that's correct, but feel free to correct me), each with one with three variant fighting styles. An incredible amount of love and care has been put into designing these characters and their fighting styles, and I can honestly say not a single one of these characters feels underbaked or half formed. It is a shame that Goro, an iconic Mortal Kombat character, is locked behind a paywall (or free if you preordered). Once you finish the story mode, there's a wealth of other play modes to muck around in. You have single fight, which lets you choose your fighter/variant and face off against a number of fighters in a stage of your choice. You always have the excellent tower modes, including the awesome Living Tower mode, which lets you run through a list of opponents as a fighter of your choice while a random event will change the fight unexpectedly (for example, the 'sloth' sends orbs into the stage that force you into slow motion if they collide with your character). This was an excellent addition, as it helps vary the gameplay even after you've played for a considerable number of hours. There's plenty of content for offline-only players here, making Mortal Kombat X worth the price purely for the single-player content. The online modes are also a hell of a lot of fun, and remain pretty addictive after investing a significant amount of hours into the game. You can choose your Faction, meaning you and other players in the same Faction will earn XP towards their Faction goal, and the winning faction for that week will allocate Krypt coins to the members of the winning team. While the online modes are excellent fun and are very substantial, the netcode is currently rather shaky and players may have trouble connecting to and remaining in a stable online game. Hopefully further patches can improve this issue.  Overall, Mortal Kombat X is an excellent fighting game; the wealth of content and sheer polish put into this title makes it worthy of purchase for long-time newcomers and even for newcomers of the franchise. I've had an excellent time playing this, and I expect I will play it for many more hours in the future. Well worth the buy, and highly recommended!

Fighting games aren't normally my sort of thing, I just can't seem to get into them enough to get good, but having played and thoroughly enjoyed NetherRealm Studio's last fighter (Injustice: Gods Among Us), I thought I'd give it a go as I've always liked the look of the Mortal Kombat series.  The story mode is as can be expected from a game of this type, essentially 4 hours of cutscenes interspersed between quick-time events and actual kombat.  Needless to say, the story hasn't exactly been the feature that has been bringing fans back time and time again, it's relatively dull in fact, but the characters and scenery are attractive enough to keep it interesting. There are a few chartacters I've had brief experience with from past MK games which are missing from the line-up, but I should think these are likely to be added as DLC further down the line. One feature that has been sure to bring fans back, is the gratuitous gore. This game had me wincing from disgust more frequently than I expected - which can only be a good thing as I've long considered myself desensitised from years of gaming. Kudos to NetherRealm Studios for that.  The way 'koins' are earnt throughout the various game types adds enjoyment to being able to unlock extras. Koins are spent in the Krypt, and all sorts of extras can be unlocked at random by exploring it. The game wasn't without its share of bugs, none of which cause any real problems, but still annoying nevertheless. For a first foray into the world of Mortal Kombat, I greatly enjoyed the experience of MKX, and would recommend it to anyone looking for an entry to the series. This is a great MK game! The online connectivity is ok. I didn't have any trouble with the matchmaking, although I did get a bit of slow down on one occasion during each of my games (didn't stop me from getting my ♥♥♥ whipped). There's tonnes of challenges both 'on the disc' and set daily via online updates, as well as a story mode similar to MK9, and a number of variations on the classic tower mode. The game looks utterly fantastic as well, and is heads and shoulders about MK9 in terms of graphical fidelity.   However, and of course there's a however because GAMES THESE DAYS, there are a few issues. Firstly, whilst gameplay is 60fps all cutscenes, X-ray scenes and fatality scenes are 30fps, which is both jarring, and utterly baffling. Scratch that, it's utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I felt much better about it when I realised it wasn't my framerate dropping but it was built into the game, but it's still ridiculous that you cut from silky smooth 60fps during a fight, to performing an X-Ray move at half that, before the game skips back to 60 when the fight resumes. Why. WHY? 60fps was good enough for MK9, why not this one? And I swear to god if someone says 'it's cinematic' I'm gonna explode. What does that word mean? Because I'm pretty sure I don't notice films skipping frames, yet here with a side-by-side comparison built into the game it's hard not to miss, and harder not to be dumbfounded by the decision. Secondly, there is some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t costly DLC skins and characters. More insultingly, the characters are visible but blacked out on the character selection screen, taunting you with their presence. On top of that, you fight some of the DLC characters in game, which is an even more egregious way of dangling the carrot in front of you.   BUT, apart from these annoying design choices/business practices, the game is a great MK game. The fatalities are more brutal than ever, the loading screens are negligible, the different play styles for the characters open up a whole new world of personalisation for the players, and there is still a fair amount of unlockable content that one can gain access to through gameplay. I especially love that some of the fatalities are hidden, so you have to hop on the internet to find out what the codes are, or unlock them in game. It's not quite the same as having to buy a magazine or ask your friends, but the sentiment is there, and it feels much more like the kind of arcade MK experience that most fans of the originals remember so fondly.   I wasn't sure about this game for months, but apparently it's a lot better now that it used to be in terms of technical integrity, and I'm just loving playing it.

I started MK with MK9 on the XB360, and thought it was okay. I did not like the gameplay with the Xbox controller and would always mess up my combos. However, I find on the PC, it is easier to master the gameplay and more fun overall IMO. One thing I liked better on MK9 was the damage to your character was much more graphic and present than in MKX. In this MK the blood kind of looks bad and characters don't get parts of their flesh and skin removed for maximum bad ♥♥♥ effect like in MK9. Also the absence of some of the cooler characters (IMO) like Kabal, Wolf, Noob, Sektor, Jade and Smoke is kind of disappointing. I do like what they have done with the krypt and like the experience of walking in first person to unlock in game items. This is just me being picky, but I wish there was an option to uninstall the krypt portion, and story portion of the game (after they have both been completed of course) as the game takes up a lot of space, and it would be nice not to have any extra dead weight after I've beaten the story and unlocked everything. However, I am very happy with the fluidity of the gameplay and when the graphics look good, they look REALLY good. I only payed $4 so I will recommend it for sure at that price, but $20 is a little steep for the lack of cool characters from MK9, and bad player damage. If you don't mind these downsides and like the MK series then I can bet you will be very happy with this game.
